THERE is no such thing as a political movement based on jokes, President Abdurrahman Wahid once wrote. But Mr. Wahid himself may be the evidence to the contrary. He jokes to relieve tension, to instruct, to make a point. In fact, his address to parliament last week sounded a bit like a nightclub act.

One joke, suggesting the need for cross-cultural understanding, involved a non-Muslim bus driver who was knocked unconscious in an accident. As he lay dying, a Muslim urged him to save his soul by calling out the name of Allah.
''Say the name! Say the name!'' the man insisted.
The bus driver opened his eyes briefly and murmured, ''Grogol,'' the name of the next stop on the line.
Here are a few more.
* Why in the tough times of former President Suharto did so many Indonesians go to Singapore for dental work? Were dentists in Indonesia so inferior?
No, it was not that. It was just that nobody in Indonesia was allowed to open his mouth.
* One day Suharto was caught in a flood and rescued by a farmer.
''Do you know who I am?'' he said. ''I'm the president of Indonesia. As thanks, I'll give you anything you want.''
''I just want one thing,'' said the farmer. ''Please don't tell anybody I rescued you.''
* When Mr. Wahid, who is virtually blind, was elected last October he named his taciturn rival, Megawati Sukarnoputri, as vice president.
''This is an ideal team,'' he said. ''The president can't see and the vice president can't talk.''
* An undertaker was unable to fold the hands of a corpse. The body was stiff and one arm remained outstretched.
''What can I do?'' he asked the local religious leader.
''What was the man's profession?''
''He was a policeman.''
''In that case,'' said the religious leader, ''just put 10,000 rupiah in his other hand and he'll bring his arm down.''
* Mr. Wahid was reported to have told this anecdote to President Clinton:
Winston Churchill was taking a walk with Clement Atlee, the Labor prime minister at the end of World War II. Churchill said he needed to relieve himself and asked for some privacy.
''Why?'' Mr. Atlee asked.
''Because,'' said Churchill, ''whenever you see something big you want to nationalize it.''
Seth Mydans
